Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Incorrect syntax near the keyword 'IF'. returned while running 201904292139301_RemoveVulnerabilityDataFromPackageDeprecationModel.cs migration" (#7931) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
I took the latest version master branch builded the solution configured the connection strings and ran: 

`Update-Database -ConfigurationTypeName MigrationsConfiguration`

in Package Manager Console on NuGetGallery project.

While running 201904292139301_RemoveVulnerabilityDataFromPackageDeprecationModel.cs migration the Incorrect syntax near the keyword 'IF'. 

The fix this I had to replace :

`Sql("ALTER TABLE [dbo].[PackageDeprecations] DROP CONSTRAINT IF EXISTS [dbo.PackageDeprecations_CVSSRating];");`
 
with

`Sql("IF EXISTS (SELECT * FROM sys.check_constraints WHERE object_id = OBJECT_ID(N'[dbo.PackageDeprecations_CVSSRating]') AND parent_object_id = OBJECT_ID(N'[dbo].[PackageDeprecations]')) ALTER TABLE dbo.PackageDeprecations DROP CONSTRAINT [dbo.PackageDeprecations_CVSSRating];");`

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "An administrator needs to claim ownership of the company by DNS validation of X before the application NuGet.Org can be provisioned" (#7932) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Trying to sign to my Nuget account and am getting this message:

```
AADSTS650051: Using application 'NuGet.Org' is currently not supported for your organization
 XXXX because it is in an unmanaged state. An administrator needs to claim ownership of the
 company by DNS validation of XXXX before the application NuGet.Org can be provisioned. 

Trace ID: 00a6abd7-0032-4e98-b22f-94d4026f4700 
Correlation ID: 3cda5e25-0c27-4c15-93df-166d1bfd9fe4 
Timestamp: 2020-04-06 16:19:09Z
```
I was able to sign to this very account just last week. How do I go about claiming the ownership?

[@MGWVc](https://twitter.com/MGWVc) `MGWVc ###` For issues regarding the NuGet client tools (the Visual Studio extension, NuGet.exe command line tool, etc.), file a bug on [NuGet Home](https://github.com/nuget/home/issues).

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[A11y]Accessibility fixes 2" (#7939) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Follow-up to https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/7927
Addresses the following issues:
[A11y]Narrator is not reading the labels for "Select Version(s)" drop-down and "Select reason(s)" check-box group #7888
 - Update the descriptions on these to indicate context.

[A11y]The narrator announces same name for all 3 actionable images present under Owner section #7883
 - Updated gravatar image alt text to include username

[A11y]Incorrect name property provided for the "Custom" tab item. #7884
 - Updated descriptions to include proper title.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[A11y]On 'T' key press in scan mode, Narrator is reading out every row in the same table" (#7892) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Copied from https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1069968
Screen Reader: 
Narrator
​
Repro Steps:​
1.Start Screen Reader. Hit the URL "https://www.nuget.org"
2.Tab till "Packages" link in the top navigation and press enter​
3.Tab till any existing package and press enter​
4.Tab till "GitHub Usage" section and press enter​ to expand it
5.Turn on scan mode for Narrator using Caps Lock+ Space bar
6.Using 'T' key, navigate to different tables on the page
7.Check if the Narrator is navigating to different rows of the same table on 'T' key press
​
Actual Result:​
On 'T' key press in scan mode, Narrator is reading out every row in the same table

NOTE: NVDA is working as expected(added attachment for reference)

Expected Result:​
On 'T' key press in scan mode, Narrator focus should navigate to different tables of the page and not to different rows in same table

Notes:
This seems related to https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7891 in the narrator is seeing tables where there are not any.
I suspect that the rows in the GitHub usage section are being read as tables, either from layout or explicit tags. We should modify this section to look more like the version table below it.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Measure PMUI tab-switching Performance" (#9350) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
When switching tabs in the PMUI, we need to be able to measure the time between the user-action, data is refreshed, and when WPF has drawn the controls.

My goal for now is to figure out a strategy for measuring this timing on my own machine, so I can recognize and report when I've made a noticeable improvement. Current plan is not to introduce such measurements to clients via telemetry, Consider this step 1 toward perf improvements, and this will surely evolve from this point.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Discuss user-study to get a baseline on Perf issues" (#9349) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "Visual Studio non-sdk style PR projects with PR items without version silently fail to add package References." (#9423) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
In a non-sdk package reference project if a PR item does not have a version:
1. Reading the package references fails without any error in the build output and the build succeeds .
The error is displayed in the "Test" result window.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16580006/79025495-cdd79a00-7b3a-11ea-802c-cda0f897ea69.png)

2. The package is not added in the solution explorer -> project -> references tree.
3. The behavior is different than the SDK style projects where in such cases the min version is used. 


VS version (if appropriate):
Microsoft Visual Studio Enterprise 2019 Int Preview
Version 16.6.0 Preview 3.0 [30006.203.master]

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Download the attached zip folder.
1. Load the project in Visual Studio.
1. Build. 

### Sample Project

[Repo.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/4463526/Repo.zip)

Events.RelatedBody:
See design document: https://github.com/NuGet/Home/blob/dev/designs/PackageReference-Extern-Alias.md

Given that this is a cross team feature, don't want to close the bug until all the partner work has been done too.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "dotnet pack does not support owners property" (#7865) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @rjgotten on March 11, 2019 15:16_

## Steps to reproduce
Try to create a package with `dotnet pack` based on `csproj` metadata properties.
Try to define owners separate from authors. E.g. where a package has a wide group of contributors but a limited set of core maintainers (or a company or other entity) that have full ownership.

## Expected  behavior
There should be an `<Owners>` metadata property in the `csproj` format which maps to the `<owners>` node in the `nuspec` format.

## Actual behavior
There is no way to set owners separate from authors without resorting to using an external `nuspec` file.

## Environment data
`dotnet --info` output:

```
.NET Core SDK (reflecting any global.json):
 Version:   2.1.504
 Commit:    91e160c7f0

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Windows
 OS Version:  10.0.17134
 OS Platform: Windows
 RID:         win10-x64
 Base Path:   C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.1.504\

Host (useful for support):
  Version: 2.1.8
  Commit:  209f8aa25c
```








_Copied from original issue: dotnet/cli#10964_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Package Manager Console should be more clear about unsupported projects" (#9421) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Solutions which have no NuGet-supported projects are causing "Package Manager Console" to show cryptic error messages.

A more preferred option would be to disable the console pane, or have some overlaying message inside the console which indicates there's nothing that this console can currently do.

At a minimum, improving the error that's shown would be more clear to the user:
Current error: "Project 'Default' is not found."
Suggestion: "The current solution doesn't contain any projects which support NuGet packages"

Here's someone failing to install a package with a "Report Server" project with this same issue:
https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/1215#issuecomment-538433452

NuGet product used: VS
Worked before? No

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Open a Python Solution in Visual Studio.
2. Open the Package Manager Console window
3. Observe that no Default projects are available:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/79004750-66622000-7b23-11ea-974d-e1caf9718b82.png)
4. Attempt to run a command such as `get-project`.
5. An error occurs due to the console being unable to choose a project in which to run this command.

> get-project : Project 'Default' is not found.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/79004859-93aece00-7b23-11ea-9233-5b7d8fdb197c.png)


## Expected

Package Manager Console is either disabled, or shows a clear error message when the solution contains no supported projects.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Manage NuGet Packages should be unavailable for unsupported projects" (#9420) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Solutions which don't support NuGet should have the "Manage NuGet Packages" options disabled, rather than having them available in a state which presents errors.

NuGet product used: VS
Worked before? No

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Open a Python Solution in Visual Studio.
2. Select Manage NuGet Packages
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/79003928-a922f880-7b21-11ea-8acf-d1c4589ec374.png)
3. An error occurs:

> Operation failed
> The project 'PythonApplication1' is unsupported
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/79004049-f1dab180-7b21-11ea-9e90-c7f4b9c3d95f.png)

4. Observe that returning to the menu, Manage NuGet Packages is now disabled.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/79004103-0b7bf900-7b22-11ea-8596-0e049ab0c02a.png)

## Expected
The disabled state in step 4. should be the state as soon as the solution is loaded.
Even better would be to hide NuGet's menu entirely.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Deprecating TLS 1.0 and 1.1 on NuGet.org – Stage 1" (#42) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
## NuGet.org will temporarily remove support for TLS 1.0/1.1 on February 26, 2020

We plan to temporarily remove support for TLS 1.0/1.1 across 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each, to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. If you discover that you are impacted and cannot identify a workaround, please open an issue on the NuGet Gallery GitHub repo.

Read this blog post to learn more and to identify the test slot time in your time zone - https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/deprecating-tls-1-0-and-1-1-on-nuget-org-stage-1/
